column8: Description
This field identifies the name of this object.

column5: follows valid BCP 47 language tag syntax
column8: The language field indicates the language tag that is used for the natural language text that is included in all of the 'description' attributes.  The language field is encoded following the rules in Section 2.1 of [RFC5646]. The default language tag is "en-US"

This field represents the type of the priority used in the policy.  Two types are defined in this module, i.e., 'priority-by-order' and 'priority-by-number'.  The 'priority-by-order' indicates that the sequence of the rules to be executed follows the input order by user.  The 'priority-by-number' indicates that the sequence of the rules to be executed follows the priority values in the rules, where a higher priority value means a higher priority. If the defined type is 'priority-by-order', the rules should not have a priority field, if the defined type is 'priority-by-number', the rules should needs a priority field.

This field represents how to resolve conflicts that occur between actions of the same or different policy rules that are matched and contained in this particular NSF.  The resolution strategy is described in Section 3.2 of [I-D.ietf-i2nsf-capability-data-model] in detail.  The default resolution strategy is "fmr" (First Matching Rule).
This field identifies the name of this object. There can be a single or multiple number of rules.

The priority of the rule to indicate the order of the rules to be matched.  A higher value means a higher priority. The packet or flow will be matched with the rule with the highest priority value first and continues to a lower priority value.  Once a rule matches the packet or flow,  the NSF should execute the rule and terminate the matching process.  If multiple rules have an equal priority, the actual order is undefined.  The handling of the selection of those rules depends on the implementer, e.g.,  an alphabetical order of the rules' names or a random rule selection.
An event (i.e., a security event) represents for which a security rule is made. System events represents the security policy rule according to system events.
An event (i.e., a security event) represents for which a security rule is made. System alarms represents the security policy rule according to system alarms.
"This describes the path of the source."
"This describes the path to the destinations."
"The transport-layer protocol to be matched."
"A start port number for a range match."
"An end port number for a range match. An end port number MUST be equal to or greater than a start port number."

column5: echo-reply, destination-unreachable, redirect, echo, router-advertisement, router-solicitation, time-exceeded, parameter-problem, experimental-mobility-protocols, extended-echo-request, extended-echo-reply,
column8: "The security policy rule according to ICMP message. The type is representing the ICMP message corresponds to the ICMP type and code."
"This is a trigger value for a rate limit of packet rate in packets per second (pps) for a DDoS-attack mitigation."
"This is a trigger value for a rate limit of byte rate in bytes per second (Bps) for a DDoS-attack mitigation."
"This is a trigger value for a rate limit of flow creating request rate (e.g., new TCP connection  establishment) in flows per second for a DDoS-attack mitigation."

"The path or name of the file that contains a security profile for the Antivirus service configuration. The security profile is used to scan the viruses. The absolute path and relative ones are to be interpreted as globs."

"The type or name of the files to be excluded by the Antivirus service.  This can be used to keep the known harmless files. Absolute paths are filenames/paths to be excluded, and relative ones are interpreted as globs."
"This describes the paths to a packet content's."
"This is description for the condition of a URL's category such as SNS sites, game sites, e-commerce sites, company sites, and university sites."

"The security policy rule according to the 'From' header field of the SIP. For the VoIP/VoCN security system, a VoIP/VoCN security system can monitor each VoIP/VoCN flow and manage VoIP/VoCN security rules controlled by a centralized server for VoIP/VoCN security service (called VoIP IPS).  The VoIP/VoCN security system controls each switch for the VoIP/VoCN call flow management by manipulating the rules that can be added, deleted, or modified dynamically. Note that VoIP is Voice over Internet Protocol and VoCN is Voice over Cellular Network such as Voice over LTE or 5G."

"The security policy rule according to the 'To' header field of the SIP. For the VoIP/VoCN security system, a VoIP/VoCN security system can monitor each VoIP/VoCN flow and manage VoIP/VoCN security rules controlled by a centralized server for VoIP/VoCN security service (called VoIP IPS).  The VoIP/VoCN security system controls each switch for the VoIP/VoCN call flow management by manipulating the rules that can be added, deleted, or modified dynamically. Note that VoIP is Voice over Internet Protocol and VoCN is Voice over Cellular Network such as Voice over LTE or 5G."

"The security policy rule according to the 'user-agent' field of the SIP. For the VoIP/VoCN security system, a VoIP/VoCN security system can monitor each VoIP/VoCN flow and manage VoIP/VoCN security rules controlled by a centralized server for VoIP/VoCN security service (called VoIP IPS).  The VoIP/VoCN security system controls each switch for the VoIP/VoCN call flow management by manipulating the rules that can be added, deleted, or modified dynamically. Note that VoIP is Voice over Internet Protocol and VoCN is Voice over Cellular Network such as Voice over LTE or 5G."
"This is the start date and time for a security policy rule."
"This is the end date and time for a security policy rule.  The policy rule will stop working after the specified end date and time."
"This is a period's start time for an event."
"This is a period's end time for an event."

column5: monday, tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday, sunday
column8: "This represents the repeated day of every week (e.g., Monday and Tuesday).  More than one day can  be specified."
"This represents the repeated day of every month. More than one date can be specified."

column5: any, but must be in the format MM-DD
column8: "The starting range of the month and date of every  year.  A pattern used here is Month and Date (MM-DD)."

column5: any, but must be in the format MM-DD
column8: "The ending range of the month and date of every year.  A pattern used here is Month and Date (MM-DD).  The 'end' value must be greater than or equal to the 'start' value."
"This represents that the rule is immediately enforced only once and not repeated. The policy will continuously be active from the start-date-time to the end-date-time."

column8: "The device attribute that can identify a device (i.e., computer, mobile phone, smartphone, VoIP/VoCN phone, tablet, network infrastructure device, IoT device, OT device, and vehicle)."

column5: pass, drop, reject, rate-limit, mirror, invoke-signaling, tunnel-encapsulation, forwarding, and transformation
column8:
"Ingress actions: pass, drop, reject, rate-limit, and mirror.
Egress actions: pass, drop, reject, rate-limit, mirror, invoke-signaling, tunnel-encapsulation, forwarding, and transformation."
"Limit is valid only when rate-limit action is used. Units is bytes per second. Specifies how to rate-limit the traffic."
"Log action: rule log and session log. Secondary actions are only logging actions."
"This represents the name of a user-group.  A user-group name is used to map a user-group's name (e.g., employees) to IP address(es), MAC address(es). It is dependent on implementation.""
"Represent the MAC Address of a user-group. A user-group can have multiple MAC Addresses."

"The IPv4 addresses in a prefix type. User must choose between IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, they cannot have both. Additionally, user must choose between IPv4 address range and prefix type, they cannot have both."

"A end IPv4 address for a range match. User must choose between IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, they cannot have both. Additionally, user must choose between IPv4 address range and prefix type, they cannot have both."

"A end IPv6 address for a range match. User must choose between IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, they cannot have both. Additionally, user must choose between IPv6 address range and prefix type, they cannot have both."
"This represents the name of a device-group. This group represents device group information to label IP (IPv4 or IPv6) addresses that provide services hosted on the application protocol."

column5: any, but must correspond to the ioc format used
column8: "This field represents the Indicators of Compromise (IOC), i.e., the critical information of patterns or characteristics (signatures) in the threat feed that identifies malicious activities. The format of the information given in this field should be parsed based on the format field (e.g., STIX, MISP, OpenIOC, and IODEF)."
"This represents the format of the IOC information. This field is mandatory to parse the IOC. The examples of the format are STIX, MISP, OpenIOC, and IODEF."
